title: Tropical Storm Nestor moves inland with strong winds, tornadoes possible
text:
CLOSE Katrina, Maria, Harvey and Sandy are all infamous names belonging to some of the worst hurricanes in history. But where do these names come from? Just the FAQs, USA TODAY

Strong winds and storm surge threatened the Florida Panhandle Saturday as Tropical Storm Nestor, now a post-tropical storm cyclone, began to move inland along the coast.

Nestor was about 70 miles west-southwest of Panama City, according to the National Hurricane Center. The storm was moving east-northeast at 9 mph, with had maximum sustained winds of 50 mph.

Nestor was expected to weaken and become a post-tropical cyclone as it moves inland over the Florida Panhandle Saturday morning or early afternoon. It was expected to cross portions of the southeastern United States later Saturday and Sunday and to move offshore of North Carolina by late Sunday.

Strong winds and storm surge threatened the Florida Panhandle Saturday as Tropical Storm Nestor began to move inland along the coast. (Photo: National Hurricane Center)

The southeast may see two to four inches of rainfall over the weekend, with up to eight inches in some places, the National Hurricane Center said.

Nestor may cause normally dry areas near the Florida coast to flood. Water levels above ground could reach as high as four feet from Indian Pass to Chassahowitzka and three feet in Tampa Bay.

The Florida Peninsula and the coastal areas of Georgia and the Carolinas may see a few tornadoes Saturday, the National Hurricane Center said.

Northwest Cape Coral sustained damage from a possible tornado Saturday morning, according to local news outlets. Some roads in Central Florida were closed because of flooding.

Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis said on Twitter that his office had received reports of tornado damage Friday night in Polk County. The Polk County Sheriff’s office reported that an apparent tornado touched down Friday night, causing damage to dozens of buildings, blowing out the windows of a home, flipping over a trailer and ripping some roofing off a middle school.

No serious injuries were reported, officials said.

We received reports of tornado damage overnight in Polk County & we are working with @FLSERT to survey damage & assist impacted areas. TS #Nestor is continuing to produce severe weather today, including the possibility of tornadoes across Central FL. Please monitor this storm. pic.twitter.com/lqQ0Udyxcb — Ron DeSantis (@GovRonDeSantis) October 19, 2019

A Tropical Storm Warning was in effect from Okaloosa/Walton County to Yankeetown, Florida.

A Storm Surge Warning was in effect for Indian Pass to Clearwater Beach, Florida.

description: Strong winds and storm surge threatened the Florida Panhandle Saturday as Tropical Storm Nestor began to move inland along the coast.
